Structure, Governance and Management
The charity is constituted as a company limited by guarantee and is governed by its Memorandum and articles
of Association.
For the purposes of improving the governance of the activities of the charity, the UK Trust has become
increasingly involved in supervising its operations in Kenya, and is in the process of taking over the Kenya
Trust responsibilities. This necessitates changes to the management structure in Kenya, in the reporting
procedures to the UK Trust, and in the frequency of meetings of the UK Trust. The charity obtained the services
of a volunteer administrator between October and December, enabling the necessary changes in Kenya to be
planned and initiated.
For reasons of governance the trustees wrote to the Charity Commission in November 2015 and received a
response in February 2016 stating that the Charity Commission had no reason not to approve the intended
actions.
With more Trustees based in the South the Board held both its meetings in London (with one of those attended
by the Executive Director of the Sanata project in Kenya). Progress in Kenya is monitored by regular Trustee
visits including during this year ones by the Chairman and 3 other trustees. The newly appointed Trustee had
lived and worked in Gilgil for a year, and whose family Trust had supported the building of the new Sanata
Orphanage (The New Restart).
All money raised by the UK Charity is transferred via Barclays Bank to a dedicated sterling account in the
Equity Bank Gilgil Kenya.
Objectives
The charity's objectives are:
~
For the relief of sickness and the preservation of good health of young and vulnerable people and the
wider community residing in Kenya by providing or assisting in the provision of healthcare projects
and facilities, buildings, fixtures, fittings, medical and other equipment and of medical expertise,
nursing, training, personnel and other resources;
The Sanata Charitable Trust

~
For the advancement of education and vocational training by providing or assisting in the provision of
youth centers, rehabilitation centers, youth and community upliftment programs, vocation training
centers, residential homes or similar institutions and all necessary support in the interest of the social
welfare if such communities with a specific emphasis on the charitable needs of young and vulnerable
people to become self-sufficient to generate a sustainable income in the future;
~
And for other purposes which are exclusively charitable.
Activities
In planning the charity's activities, the trustees have had regard to the guidance issued by the Charity
commission on Public Benefit.
The main activities in relation to these objects are the raising of funds to support the health, education and
general wellbeing of young and vulnerable people in Kenya, overseeing the operation of the Sanata Orphanage,
and ensuring proper and accountable use of the funds raised.
Achievements and Performance
The new Restart building has now been occupied for 15 months, and is proving to be an excellent resource.
The children are flourishing in their new home, its design has proved to be highly effective, and its location
away from the urban area is a safer environment.
The new website (www restartafrlca org) is now well-established, and the improved structure of the charity
incorporates updates on a regular basis.
The UK Charity's main concern has always been the Restart but its original Memorandum and Articles also
emphasised a commitment to self-sufficiency and general uplift in the deprived community of Gilgil. Small
business enterprises such as craft and desi~, and the manufacture of briquettes (from waste paper) have been
in existence for some time but require financial support. It is pleasing that the improved accounting and
management structure has brought them closer to breaking even. In the long term it is intended that these
commercial enterprises will contribute significantly to the financing of the Restart.
In terms of income, the Charity has had a satisfactory year but remains very conscious of the challenge of core
funding as the costs have increased significantly with the new building allowing the number of children looked
atter to approximately double. It has always been the Charity's avowed aim to see the Restart children through
to a purposeful stage in their lives and this means education as well as basic care. As the children get older,
more are attending secondary schools, which are significantly more expensive than primary schools.
Achievements and ambitions are considerable —one Restart boy is already at University, and by next
September 4 more will be at university, but these things cost and the Trustees have made fund -raising a key
part of their responsibility.
In order to align the UK and Kenyan accounts, allowing for tighter financial control, the UK trust has changed
its accounting period to end on 31 December from 2015 onwards.
Reserves policy
The charity has applied all its net income for the benefit of the Restart in Kenya, in accordance with its
objectives. The reserves policy is to continue to build funds for this purpose.

Financial Review
The financial accounts for the sixteen months ended 31 December 2015 have been prepared and approved by
the Trustees.
The period ended 31 December 2015 has shown a substantial increase in the unrestricted funds raised.
Income in the year ended 31 August 2014 was higher based on specific donations for the Restart new build
and related projects. As the operating costs of the Restart increase the trustees focus is on ensuring the
funding available to meet those costs.
Sources of funds include fundraising events, standing orders, single donations, either on-line or by post, and
donations from family charities.
Risk Management
The trustees have considered the major risks to which the charity may become exposed and, following an
external review by an independent firm of chartered accountants, have further reviewed those risks and are
establishing systems and procedures to manage these and to be able to deal with any unforeseen eventualities
that may occur in the future. .

Fund accounting
General funds are unrestricted funds which are available for use at the discretion
of the trustees in furtherance of the general objectives of the charity and which
have not been designated for other purposes. Designated funds are unrestricted
funds allocated by the Board of Trustees for particular purposes. Funds which
have been applied for and received for a particular purpose are considered to be
designated and are therefore treated as unrestricted within the meaning of the
regulations.
Restricted funds are subject to restriction on their expenditure imposed by the

of raising and administering such funds are charged against the specific fund. Any
fund which, upon full performance, would require the retrieval by the authority
concerned of any surplus is considered to be restricted for the purposes of

Structure, Governance and Management
The charity is constituted as a company limited by guarantee and is governed by its Memorandum and articles
of Association.
For the purposes of improving the governance of the activities of the charity, the UK Trust has become
increasingly involved in supervising its operations in Kenya, and is in the process of taking over the Kenya
Trust responsibilities. This necessitates changes to the management structure in Kenya, in the reporting
procedures to the UK Trust, and in the frequency of meetings of the UK Trust. The charity obtained the services
of a volunteer administrator between October and December, enabling the necessary changes in Kenya to be
planned and initiated.
For reasons of governance the trustees wrote to the Charity Commission in November 2015 and received
a
response in February 2016 stating that the Charity Commission had no reason not to approve the intended
actions.
With more Trustees based in the South the Board held both its meetings in London (with one of those attended
by the Executive Director of the Sanata project in Kenya). Progress in Kenya is monitored by regular Trustee
visits including during this year ones by the Chairman and 3 other trustees. The newly appointed Trustee had
lived and worked in Gilgil for a year, and whose family Trust had supported the building of the new Sanata
Orphanage (The New Restart).
All money raised by the UK Charity is transferred via Barclays Bank to a dedicated sterling account in the
Equity Bank Gilgil Kenya.
Objectives
The charity's objectives are:
For the relief of sickness and the preservation of good health of young and vulnerable people and the
wider community residing in Kenya by providing or assisting in the provision of healthcare projects
and facilities, buildings, fixtures, fittings, medical and other equipment and of medical expertise,
nursing, training, personnel and other resources;

For the advancement of education and vocational training by providing or assisting in the provision of
youth centers, rehabilitation centers, youth and community upliftment programs, vocation training
centers, residential homes or similar institutions and all necessary support in the interest of the social
welfare if such communities with a specific emphasis on the charitable needs of young and vulnerable
people to become self-sufficient to generate a sustainable income in the future;
And for other purposes which are exclusively charitable.
Activities
In planning the charity's activities, the trustees have had regard to the guidance issued by the Charity
commission on Public Benefit.
The main activities in relation to these objects are the raising of funds to support the health, education and
general wellbeing of young and vulnerable people in Kenya, overseeing the operation of the Sanata Orphanage,
and ensuring proper and accountable use of the funds raised.
Achievements and Performance
The new Restart building has now been occupied for 15 months, and is proving to be an excellent resource.
The children are flourishing in their new home, its design has proved to be highly effective, and its location
away from the urban area is a safer environment.
The new website (www.restartafrica.org) is now well-established, and the improved structure of the charity
incorporates updates on a regular basis.
The UK Charity's main concern has always been the Restart but its original Memorandum and Articles also
emphasised a commitment to self-sufficiency and general uplift in the deprived community of Gilgil. Small
business enterprises such as craft and design, and the manufacture of briquettes (from waste paper) have been
in existence for some time but require financial support. It is pleasing that the improved accounting and
management structure has brought them closer to breaking even. In the long term it is intended that these
commercial enterprises will contribute significantly to the financing of the Restart.
In terms of income, the Charity has had a satisfactory year but remains very conscious of the challenge of core
funding as the costs have increased significantly with the new building allowing the number of children looked
after to approximately double. It has always been the Charity's avowed aim to see the Restart children through
to a purposeful stage in their lives and this means education as well as basic care. As the children get older,
more are attending secondary schools, which are significantly more expensive than primary schools.
Achievements and ambitions are considerable - one Restart boy is already at University, and by next
September 4 more will be at university, but these things cost and the Trustees have made fund -raising a key
part of their responsibility.
In order to align the UK and Kenyan accounts, allowing for tighter financial control, the UK trust has changed
its accounting period to end on 31 December from 2015 onwards.
Reserves policy
The charity has applied all its net income for the benefit of the Restart in Kenya, in accordance with its
objectives. The reserves policy is to continue to build funds for this purpose.

Cantate exists to develop and promote choral singing and other musical ability to the highest
standards by young people between the ages of eight and eighteen years. It currently comprises
Training Choir, Youth Choir and Senior Choir sections. Its main centre of operation and rehearsals is
Bishop’s Stortford, Hertfordshire, and its members are drawn from the Hertfordshire,
Cambridgeshire, and Essex. It consists of up to 160 singers, drawn from a wide range of schools
across this region.
Constitution: The charity is governed by the Cantate Youth Choir constitution, drawn up in February
1994, which has the following objective:
‘The objective of the Society shall be to promote, improve, develop and maintain public education
and appreciation of choral music in all its aspects by the presentation of public concerts and recitals
and by such other ways as the Society, through its Committee, shall determine from time to time.’
The management of the Society is in the hands of a committee consisting of an Honorary Chairman,
Honorary Secretary and Honorary Treasurer, together with no fewer than three other members. The
officers and other committee members are elected by, and out of, the Society’s members at the
Annual General Meeting. They hold office for one year and are eligible for re-election.
The members of the Cantate committee are regarded de facto as the Trustees of the charity, and the
responsibilities of Trustees are made clear to all committee members on election and with regard to
business conducted in committee meetings. The General Manager, and one or more Music Directors
are ex-officio members of the committee.
Trustees/elected committee members receive no remuneration from the charity.
A list of Trustees for 2013 is given below.

3BT

Management: Day to day organisation and management of Cantate is carried out by the General
Manager, who reports to the Committee via the Honorary Chairman. Terms and conditions for this
post are set by a sub-committee of the Trustees. A job description, together with annual and longer
term objectives for the General Manager is set out by the Trustees. The services of the music staff,
including the Music Directors, are provided on a freelance basis.
All other positions and responsibilities within Cantate are filled by volunteer members of the Society,
who are most often parents of members. These roles include office support, music librarian, choir
managers, transport and staging, catering, event management, costumes, tour leaders, first aid,
pastoral care, etc.
Cantate has a policy of securing enhanced CRB checks for all volunteers and staff who come into
contact with members of the choirs.
Subscription fees are charged per term to members of the choirs. The Trustees have due regard to
maintaining these at an affordable level, to ensure that the choirs can be as inclusive in membership
as possible. A bursary fund is maintained for the support of members in lower-income families.
Cantate has clear regard to the public benefit of its charitable status:

Entry to Cantate Training Choir and Youth choir is entirely open and free of audition
requirements, and is limited only by the viability of choir sizes. (Membership of the Senior Choir
requires an adequate musical standard to have been reached.)

Cantate exists to develop and promote singing and musical ability in young people, and has a
strong educational, social and community ethos.

Cantate performs to a wide range of audiences, including local communities, and at national and
international level.

Cantate performs at charitable events such as the British Legion Christmas Celebration, as well
as at local level for hospices and other causes.

Cantate has participated in the Sing Up project, performing alongside school choirs in a
mentoring and exemplar role.

Cantate holds Fun Sing events every year, which are open to local young people who are new to
singing.

Cantate participates with other local youth choirs and musicians in joint events where the
experience of its singers can benefit other groups.

Membership of Cantate is diverse in terms of social background and abilities.

Musical objectives for Cantate choirs are set by the Music Directors, working with the General
Manager and by agreement with the Trustees.
In January 2010 Nicholas Shaw and Graham Instrall took over the role of joint Music Directors,
following on from Michael Kibblewhite, who became Founder Music Director at the end of 1994.

Cantate exists to develop and promote choral singing and other musical ability to the highest
standards by young people between the ages of eight and eighteen years. It currently comprises
Training Choir, Youth Choir and Senior Choir sections. Its main centre of operation and rehearsals is
Bishop's Stortford, Hertfordshire, and its members are drawn from the Hertfordshire,
Cambridgeshire, and Essex. It consists of up to 160 singers, drawn from a wide range of schools
across this region.
Constitution: The charity is governed by the Cantate Youth Choir constitution, drawn up in February
1994, which has the following objective:
'The objective of the Society shall be to promote, improve, develop and maintain public education
and appreciation of choral music in all its aspects by the presentation of public concerts and recitals
and by such other ways as the Society, through its Committee, shall determine from time to time.'
The management of the Society is in the hands of a committee consisting of an Honorary Chairman,
Honorary Secretary and Honorary Treasurer, together with no fewer than three other members. The
officers and other committee members are elected by, and out of, the Society's members at the
Annual General Meeting. They hold office for one year and are eligible for re-election.
The members of the Cantate committee are regarded de facto as the Trustees of the charity, and the
responsibilities of Trustees are made clear to all committee members on election and with regard to
business conducted in committee meetings. The General Manager, and one or more Music Directors
are ex-officio members of the committee.
Trustees/elected committee members receive no remuneration from the charity.
A list of Trustees for 2013 is given below.

Management: Day to day organisation and management of Cantate is carried out by the General
Manager, who reports to the Committee via the Honorary Chairman. Terms and conditions for this
post are set by a sub-committee of the Trustees. A job description, together with annual and longer
term objectives for the General Manager is set out by the Trustees. The services of the music staff,
including the Music Directors, are provided on a freelance basis.
AIl other positions and responsibilities within Cantate are filled by volunteer members of the Society,
who are most often parents of members. These roles include office support, music librarian, choir
managers, transport and staging, catering, event management, costumes, tour leaders, first aid,
pastoral care, etc.
Cantate has a policy of securing enhanced CRB checks for all volunteers and staff who come into
contact with members of the choirs.
Subscription fees are charged per term to members of the choirs. The Trustees have due regard to
maintaining these at an affordable level, to ensure that the choirs can be as inclusive in membership
as possible. A bursary fund is maintained for the support of members in lower-income families.
Cantate has clear regard to the public benefit of its charitable status:
Entry to Cantate Training Choir and Youth choir is entirely open and free of audition
requirements, and is limited only by the viability of choir sizes. (Membership of the Senior Choir
requires an adequate musical standard to have been reached.)
Cantate exists to develop and promote singing and musical ability in young people, and has a
strong educational, social and community ethos.
Cantate performs to a wide range of audiences, including local communities, and at national and
internationa level.
Cantate performs at charitable events such as the British Legion Christmas Celebration, as well
as at local level for hospices and other causes.
Cantate has participated in the Sing Up project, performing alongside school choirs in
a
mentoring and exemplar role.
Cantate holds Fun Sing events every year, which are open to local young people who are new to
singing.
Cantate participates with other local youth choirs and musicians in joint events where the
experience of its singers can benefit other groups.
Membership of Cantate is diverse in terms of social background and abilities.
Musical objectives for Cantate choirs are set by the Music Directors, working with the General
Manager and by agreement with the Trustees.
In January 2010 Nicholas Shaw and Graham Instrall took over the role of joint Music Directors,
following on from Michael Kibblewhite, who became Founder Music Director at the end of 1994.

NOTES TO THE ACCOUNTS for the YEAR ENDED 31st December 2013
1. ACCOUNTING POLICIES
1.1 Basis of Preparation
Basis of Accounting: These accounts have been prepared under the historic cost convention and in accordance with
applicable accounting standards and the Statement of Recommended Practice on Accounting by Charities.
Changes in Basis of Accounting: There has been no change to the accounting policies (valuation rules and methods of
accounting) since last year.
Changes to previous accounts: No changes have been made to accounts for previous years.
1,2 Incoming Resources
Income Recognition: These are included in the Statement of Financial Activities (SoFA) when the charity becomes
entitled to the resources:-
The trustees are virtually certain they will receive the resources;
The monetary value can be measured with sufficient reliability.
Grants: Grants awarded to the Charity are restricted to Capital Expenditure on Fixed Assets are not recorded as
income, but are instead released on an annual basis in line with the concerned asset's depreciation. The balance of
the received grant is held as Restricted Funds. Grants awarded that are restricted to expenditure on current assets
and services or are not stipulated are shown as income. Where the expenditure is to made in further years, accruals
are made based on anticipated spread of expenditure. Such accrued and unreleased grants are held as restricted
funds where stipulated or otherwise as designated funds.
1.3 Expenditure and Liabilities
Liability Recognition: Liabilities are recognised as soon as there is a lega or constructive obligation committing the
charity to pay out resources
VAT: As a charity not registered for VAT, all VAT is unrecoverable. All liabilities and expenditure shown includes VAT
paid.
1.4 Tangible Fixed Assets
Depreciation: Depreciation is provided on the office equipment, staging and sound equipment based on the
estimated useful life of these fixed assets and their anticipated residual value at the rate of 25 per cent per annum
of the residual balance
Stock: Stock is valued at the lower of cost and net realisable value.

Cantate exists to develop and promote choral singing and other musical ability to the highest
standards by young people between the ages of eight and eighteen years. It currently comprises
Training Choir, Youth Choir and Senior Choir sections. Its main centre of operation and rehearsals is
Bishop’s Stortford, Hertfordshire, and its members are drawn from the Hertfordshire,
Cambridgeshire, and Essex. It consists of up to 160 singers, drawn from a wide range of schools
across this region.
Constitution: The charity is governed by the Cantate Youth Choir constitution, drawn up in February
1994, which has the following objective:
‘The objective of the Society shall be to promote, improve, develop and maintain public education
and appreciation of choral music in all its aspects by the presentation of public concerts and recitals
and by such other ways as the Society, through its Committee, shall determine from time to time.’
The management of the Society is in the hands of a committee consisting of an Honorary Chairman,
Honorary Secretary and Honorary Treasurer, together with no fewer than three other members. The
officers and other committee members are elected by, and out of, the Society’s members at the
Annual General Meeting. They hold office for one year and are eligible for re-election.
The members of the Cantate committee are regarded de facto as the Trustees of the charity, and the
responsibilities of Trustees are made clear to all committee members on election and with regard to
business conducted in committee meetings. The General Manager, and one or more Music Directors
are ex-officio members of the committee.
Trustees/elected committee members receive no remuneration from the charity.

Management: Day to day organisation and management of Cantate is carried out by the General
Manager, who reports to the Committee via the Honorary Chairman. Terms and conditions for this
post are set by a sub-committee of the Trustees. A job description, together with annual and longer
term objectives for the General Manager is set out by the Trustees. The services of the music staff,
including the Music Directors, are provided on a freelance basis.
All other positions and responsibilities within Cantate are filled by volunteer members of the Society,
who are most often parents of members. These roles include office support, music librarian, choir
managers, transport and staging, catering, event management, costumes, tour leaders, first aid,
pastoral care, etc.
Cantate has a policy of securing enhanced CRB checks for all volunteers and staff who come into
contact with members of the choirs.
Subscription fees are charged per term to members of the choirs. The Trustees have due regard to
maintaining these at an affordable level, to ensure that the choirs can be as inclusive in membership
as possible. A bursary fund is maintained for the support of members in lower-income families.
Cantate has clear regard to the public benefit of its charitable status:
e Entry to Cantate Training Choir and Youth choir is entirely open and free of audition
requirements, and is limited only by the viability of choir sizes. (Membership of the Senior Choir
requires an adequate musical standard to have been reached.)
e Cantate exists to develop and promote singing and musical ability in young people, and has a
strong educational, social and community ethos.
e Cantate performs to a wide range of audiences, including local communities, and at national and
international level.
e Cantate performs at charitable events such as the British Legion Christmas Celebration, as well
as at local level for hospices and other causes.
e Cantate has participated in the Sing Up project, performing alongside school choirs in a
mentoring and exemplar role.
e Cantate holds Fun Sing events every year, which are open to local young people who are new to
singing.
e Cantate participates with other local youth choirs and musicians in joint events where the
experience of its singers can benefit other groups.
e Membership of Cantate is diverse in terms of social background and abilities.
e Musical objectives for Cantate choirs are set by the Music Directors, working with the General
Manager and by agreement with the Trustees.
In January 2010 Nicholas Shaw and Graham Instrall took over the role of joint Music Directors,
following on from Michael Kibblewhite, who became Founder Music Director at the end of 1994.

Type of governing document: The Group's governing documents are those of the scout
Association. They consist of a Royar charter, which in turn gives authority to the Bye Laws
of the Association and The Policy, organisation and Rules of The Scout Association.
How the charity is constituted: The Group is a trust established under its rules which are
common to allScouts'
Trustee selection methods: The Trustees are appointed in accordance with the Policy,
Organisation and Rules of The Scout Association'
Additional governance issues: The Group is managed by the Group Executive Committee' the
members of which are the
,charity Trustees' of the scout Group which is an educational
charity. As charity trustees they are responsible for complying with legislation applicable
to charities. This includes the registration, keeping proper accounts and making returns to
the Charity Commission as appropriate.
The Committee consists of 3 independent representatives, Chair, Treasurer and Secretary
together with the Group Scout Leader, parent's representation and meets 6 times a year.
This Group Executive Committee exists to support the Group Scout Leader in meeting the
responsibilities of the appointments and is responsible for:
The maintenance of Group property;
The raising of funds and the administration of Group finance; The insurance of persons,
property and equipment; Group public occasions;
Assisting in the recruitment of leaders and other adult supporU Appointing any sub
committees that may be required;
Appointing Group Administrators and Advisors other than those who are elected.
Risk and internal control: The group has in place systems of internal controls that are designed
to provide reasonable assurance against material mismanagement or loss, these include 2
signatories for all payments and comprehensive insurance policies to ensure that
insurable risks are covered.
The objectives of the group are as a unit of the Scout Association. The Aim of The Scout
Association is to promote the development of young people in achieving their full physical,
intetlectual, social and spiritual potentials, as individuals, as responsible citizens and as members
of their tocal national and international communities. The method of achieving the Aim of the
Association is by providing an enjoyable and attractive scheme of progressive training, based on
the Scout Promise and Law and guided by adult leadership.
Throughout the year there have been six sections meeting on a weekly basis during term time:
Quebec and Yukon (Beavers), Jubilee and Jungle (Cubs) and Victory and Endeavour (scouts).
Across allthe sections, activities were chosen and organised by leaders, with help on a week-to-
week basis from parent volunteers, to enable children to earn specific activity badges as well as
to meet the criteria for the challenge badges. Activities have ranged from opportunities to
handle reptiles to first aid practice, from campfire cooking and whittling to races and games,
from night to visiting places of worship.
There have been opportunities for young people in allsections to spend 'nights away', from a
night away in tepees for the Beaver age group, to sleepovers and camps for the Cubs and a
variety of camps and expeditions for the Scouts.
Public benefit statement: The Group meets the Charity Commission's public benefit criteria
under both the advancement of education and the advancement of citizenship or
community development headings.
After a successful parents' quiz night to raise funds for the Group, the Cubs and Scouts had the
opportunity to demonstrate their general knowledge at their own quiz nights which were equally
wellenjoyed.
One member of Endeavour Scout troop, Rebecca, was selected to take part in a youth-led
international camp in Switzerland. The Scouts took part in a sponsored hike to raise money for
Rebecca and raised more than was needed so were able to buy more camping equipment with
the extra money.
The Summer barbecue and AGM was again popular and was the main fundraising event of the
year, raising just over f 1.200.
Four young leaders attached to the group completed their Duke of Edinburgh Award - one
gained bronze and three gained silver awards.
The Group applied for and received a f3000 grant from Wooburn Parish council. This was used
to buy and install security lights for the outside of the building to complement the new security
system and also to buy additional equipment for the Group Camp.
We held a Group Camp at Paccar in June - the first for many years. Over 100 children and young
people from the Group took part, with Beavers visiting for the day and Cubs, Scouts and Young
Leaders camping for two nights. The money from the grant paid for enough tents for all the
young people to sleep in!
Thirty six children in the Group received their Chief Scout awards during the year.
Several teams of Scouts entered the County Orienteering competition, the Big '0', held in
Wendover Woods in October 2015. One of the Bourne End teams came second.
Reserves Policy: The Group's poliry on reserves is to hold sufficient resources to continue the
charitable activities of the group should income and fundraising activities fall short. The
Group Executive Committee considers that the group should hold a sum equivalent to
f4500 to ensure that there will be enough money to cover any emergency repairs and
replacements e.g. to the heating in the Scout Hut.
The Group held reserves of approximately f,L?7OO against this at year end. This is above
the level required for operating expenses. However this can be explained by a substantial
sum of money that was bequeathed to the Scout Group a few years ago by a local
resident to ensure the continuation of Scouting in Bourne End.
lnvestment policy: The Group does not have sufficient funds to invest in longer term
investments. The Group has therefore adopted a risk averse strategy to the investment of
its funds. Allfunds are held in cash using only mainstream banks or building societies.
The Group would like to become more involved with the localcommunity and make a bigger
impact on Bourne End Night.
It remains a priority to increase the number of leaders for Jubilee Cub pack as there are currently
only 2 leaders on a Wednesday evening. We would also like to increase the number of young
leaders assisting in all sections and increase the quality of their training.
We have moved forward with the idea of a group website and one of our leaders has begun work
on it. We hope to launch it soon.
The construction of a World War One trench will be repeated in the back room of the Scout Hut
in November, following the success of the previous trench exhibition in 20L4.
The Group will be supporting one of the Explorer Scouts, Jack, in his fundraising for a trip to
Ecuador run through a youth scheme at his school.

Section B Structure, governance and management
Type of governing document: The Group's governing documents are those of the Scout
Association. They consist of a Royal Charter, which in turn gives authority to the Bye Laws
of the Association and The Policy, Organisation and Rules of The Scout Association.
How the charity is constituted: The Group is a trust established under its rules which are
common to all Scouts.
Trustee selection methods: The Trustees are appointed in accordance with the Policy,
Organisation and Rules of The Scout Association.
Additional governance issues: The Group is managed by the Group Executive Committee, the
members of which are the ‘Charity Trustees’ of the Scout Group which is an educational
charity. As charity trustees they are responsible for complying with legislation applicable
to charities. This includes the registration, keeping proper accounts and making returns to
the Charity Commission as appropriate.
The Committee consists of 3 independent representatives, Chair, Treasurer and Secretary
together with the Group Scout Leader, parent’s representation and meets 6 times a year.
This Group Executive Committee exists to support the Group Scout Leader in meeting the
responsibilities of the appointments and is responsible for:
The maintenance of Group property;
The raising of funds and the administration of Group finance; The insurance of persons,
property and equipment; Group public occasions;
Assisting in the recruitment of leaders and other adult support; Appointing any sub
committees that may be required;
Appointing Group Administrators and Advisors other than those who are elected.
Risk and internal control: The group has in place systems of internal controls that are designed
to provide reasonable assurance against material mismanagement or loss, these include 2
signatories for all payments and comprehensive insurance policies to ensure that
insurable risks are covered.
Section C Objectives and activities
The objectives of the group are as a unit of the Scout Association. The Aim of The Scout
Association is to promote the development of young people in achieving their full physical,
intellectual, social and spiritual potentials, as individuals, as responsible citizens and as members
of their local national and international communities. The method of achieving the Aim of the
Association is by providing an enjoyable and attractive scheme of progressive training, based on
the Scout Promise and Law and guided by adult leadership.
Throughout the year there have been six sections meeting on a weekly basis during term time:
Quebec and Yukon (Beavers), Jubilee and Jungle (Cubs) and Victory and Endeavour (Scouts).
Across all the sections, activities were chosen and organised by leaders, with help on a week-to-
week basis from parent volunteers, to enable children to earn specific activity badges as well as
to meet the criteria for the challenge badges. Activities have ranged from opportunities to
handle reptiles to first aid practice, from campfire cooking and whittling to races and games,
from night to visiting places of worship.
There have been opportunities for young people in all sections to spend ‘nights away’, from a
night away in tepees for the Beaver age group, to sleepovers and camps for the Cubs and a
variety of camps and expeditions for the Scouts.
Public benefit statement: The Group meets the Charity Commission's public benefit criteria
under both the advancement of education and the advancement of citizenship or
community development headings.
Section D Achievements and performance
After a successful parents’ quiz night to raise funds for the Group, the Cubs and Scouts had the
opportunity to demonstrate their general knowledge at their own quiz nights which were equally
well enjoyed.
One member of Endeavour Scout troop, Rebecca, was selected to take part in a youth-led
international camp in Switzerland. The Scouts took part in a sponsored hike to raise money for
Rebecca and raised more than was needed so were able to buy more camping equipment with
the extra money.
The Summer barbecue and AGM was again popular and was the main fundraising event of the
year, raising just over £1200.
Four young leaders attached to the group completed their Duke of Edinburgh Award — one
gained bronze and three gained silver awards.
The Group applied for and received a £3000 grant from Wooburn Parish council. This was used
to buy and install security lights for the outside of the building to complement the new security
system and also to buy additional equipment for the Group Camp.
We held a Group Camp at Paccar in June — the first for many years. Over 100 children and young
people from the Group took part, with Beavers visiting for the day and Cubs, Scouts and Young
Leaders camping for two nights. The money from the grant paid for enough tents for all the
young people to sleep in!
Thirty six children in the Group received their Chief Scout awards during the year.
Several teams of Scouts entered the County Orienteering competition, the Big ‘0’, held in
Wendover Woods in October 2015. One of the Bourne End teams came second.
Section E Financial Review
Reserves Policy: The Group's policy on reserves is to hold sufficient resources to continue the
charitable activities of the group should income and fundraising activities fall short. The
Group Executive Committee considers that the group should hold a sum equivalent to
£4500 to ensure that there will be enough money to cover any emergency repairs and
replacements e.g. to the heating in the Scout Hut.
The Group held reserves of approximately £12700 against this at year end. This is above
the level required for operating expenses. However this can be explained by a substantial
sum of money that was bequeathed to the Scout Group a few years ago by a local
resident to ensure the continuation of Scouting in Bourne End.
Investment policy: The Group does not have sufficient funds to invest in longer term
investments. The Group has therefore adopted a risk averse strategy to the investment of
its funds. All funds are held in cash using only mainstream banks or building societies.
Section F Other optional information
The Group would like to become more involved with the local community and make a bigger
impact on Bourne End Night.
It remains a priority to increase the number of leaders for Jubilee Cub pack as there are currently
only 2 leaders on a Wednesday evening. We would also like to increase the number of young
leaders assisting in all sections and increase the quality of their training.
We have moved forward with the idea of a group website and one of our leaders has begun work
on it. We hope to launch it soon.
The construction of a World War One trench will be repeated in the back room of the Scout Hut
in November, following the success of the previous trench exhibition in 2014.
The Group will be supporting one of the Explorer Scouts, Jack, in his fundraising for a trip to
Ecuador run through a youth scheme at his school.

Type of governing document: The Group's governing documents are those of the scout
Association. They consist of a Royar charter, which in turn gives authority to the Bye Laws
of the Association and The Policy, organisation and Rules of The Scout Association.
How the charity is constituted: The Group is a trust established under its rules which are
common to allScouts'
Trustee selection methods: The Trustees are appointed in accordance with the Policy,
Organisation and Rules of The Scout Association'
Additional governance issues: The Group is managed by the Group Executive Committee' the
members of which are the
,charity Trustees' of the scout Group which is an educational
charity. As charity trustees they are responsible for complying with legislation applicable
to charities. This includes the registration, keeping proper accounts and making returns to
the Charity Commission as appropriate.
The Committee consists of 3 independent representatives, Chair, Treasurer and Secretary
together with the Group Scout Leader, parent's representation and meets 6 times a year.
This Group Executive Committee exists to support the Group Scout Leader in meeting the
responsibilities of the appointments and is responsible for:
The maintenance of Group property;
The raising of funds and the administration of Group finance; The insurance of persons,
property and equipment; Group public occasions;
Assisting in the recruitment of leaders and other adult supporU Appointing any sub
committees that may be required;
Appointing Group Administrators and Advisors other than those who are elected.
Risk and internal control: The group has in place systems of internal controls that are designed
to provide reasonable assurance against material mismanagement or loss, these include 2
signatories for all payments and comprehensive insurance policies to ensure that
insurable risks are covered.
The objectives of the group are as a unit of the Scout Association. The Aim of The Scout
Association is to promote the development of young people in achieving their full physical,
intetlectual, social and spiritual potentials, as individuals, as responsible citizens and as members
of their tocal national and international communities. The method of achieving the Aim of the
Association is by providing an enjoyable and attractive scheme of progressive training, based on
the Scout Promise and Law and guided by adult leadership.
Throughout the year there have been six sections meeting on a weekly basis during term time:
Quebec and Yukon (Beavers), Jubilee and Jungle (Cubs) and Victory and Endeavour (scouts).
Across allthe sections, activities were chosen and organised by leaders, with help on a week-to-
week basis from parent volunteers, to enable children to earn specific activity badges as well as
to meet the criteria for the challenge badges. Activities have ranged from opportunities to
handle reptiles to first aid practice, from campfire cooking and whittling to races and games,
from night to visiting places of worship.
There have been opportunities for young people in allsections to spend 'nights away', from a
night away in tepees for the Beaver age group, to sleepovers and camps for the Cubs and a
variety of camps and expeditions for the Scouts.
Public benefit statement: The Group meets the Charity Commission's public benefit criteria
under both the advancement of education and the advancement of citizenship or
community development headings.
After a successful parents' quiz night to raise funds for the Group, the Cubs and Scouts had the
opportunity to demonstrate their general knowledge at their own quiz nights which were equally
wellenjoyed.
One member of Endeavour Scout troop, Rebecca, was selected to take part in a youth-led
international camp in Switzerland. The Scouts took part in a sponsored hike to raise money for
Rebecca and raised more than was needed so were able to buy more camping equipment with
the extra money.
The Summer barbecue and AGM was again popular and was the main fundraising event of the
year, raising just over f 1.200.
Four young leaders attached to the group completed their Duke of Edinburgh Award - one
gained bronze and three gained silver awards.
The Group applied for and received a f3000 grant from Wooburn Parish council. This was used
to buy and install security lights for the outside of the building to complement the new security
system and also to buy additional equipment for the Group Camp.
We held a Group Camp at Paccar in June - the first for many years. Over 100 children and young
people from the Group took part, with Beavers visiting for the day and Cubs, Scouts and Young
Leaders camping for two nights. The money from the grant paid for enough tents for all the
young people to sleep in!
Thirty six children in the Group received their Chief Scout awards during the year.
Several teams of Scouts entered the County Orienteering competition, the Big '0', held in
Wendover Woods in October 2015. One of the Bourne End teams came second.
Reserves Policy: The Group's poliry on reserves is to hold sufficient resources to continue the
charitable activities of the group should income and fundraising activities fall short. The
Group Executive Committee considers that the group should hold a sum equivalent to
f4500 to ensure that there will be enough money to cover any emergency repairs and
replacements e.g. to the heating in the Scout Hut.
The Group held reserves of approximately f,L?7OO against this at year end. This is above
the level required for operating expenses. However this can be explained by a substantial
sum of money that was bequeathed to the Scout Group a few years ago by a local
resident to ensure the continuation of Scouting in Bourne End.
lnvestment policy: The Group does not have sufficient funds to invest in longer term
investments. The Group has therefore adopted a risk averse strategy to the investment of
its funds. Allfunds are held in cash using only mainstream banks or building societies.
The Group would like to become more involved with the localcommunity and make a bigger
impact on Bourne End Night.
It remains a priority to increase the number of leaders for Jubilee Cub pack as there are currently
only 2 leaders on a Wednesday evening. We would also like to increase the number of young
leaders assisting in all sections and increase the quality of their training.
We have moved forward with the idea of a group website and one of our leaders has begun work
on it. We hope to launch it soon.
The construction of a World War One trench will be repeated in the back room of the Scout Hut
in November, following the success of the previous trench exhibition in 20L4.
The Group will be supporting one of the Explorer Scouts, Jack, in his fundraising for a trip to
Ecuador run through a youth scheme at his school.
